section.title: Quantifiers
section.sectiontitle: We use quantifiers to talk about how much or how many there are of something. With countable nouns and uncountable nouns we can use (not) any, (not) enough, a lot of, lots of, no, plenty of and some.
section.text1a: There are lots of parks and no problems with traffic.
section.sectiontitle2: We use (too) many, several, a few, a couple (of) and one or two with countable nouns and (too) much, a bit of, a little with uncountable nouns.
section.text3a: There are several patients in the waiting room.

section.title: Quantifiers
section.sectiontitle: We usually use some in positive sentences to mean a limited quantity or number of something. We also use it in questions when we make requests and offers.
section.text1: I don't like all pop music.
section.text2a: Can you give me some information, please?
section.sectiontitle2: We often use any in negatives and questions.

section.title: Quantifiers
section.sectiontitle: We usually use a lot of/lots of in informal positive sentences. Loads of is very informal.
section.text1a: We sell a lot of imported goods.
section.sectiontitle2: We generally use much and many in informal speech and writing for negatives and questions.
section.text3a: I haven't got much money with me.

section.title: Quantifiers
section.sectiontitle: We use too much and too many when there is more of something than we need. It has a negative meaning.
section.text1a: Do you want some of my pizza? There's too much for me.
section.text2a: Let's go somewhere else. There are too many people in here.
section.sectiontitle2: We use enough to mean as much as we need. We use plenty of to mean more than enough. It has a positive meaning.
section.text3a: Have we got enough chairs for everyone?
section.text4a: We've got plenty of sandwiches for everyone – we don't need any more.
